comment._content: Wonderful image.  The tram is more like a small train.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
There is an earlier photo at the same corner.  The building on the corner (Thomas the Tank Engine Hotel?) is being built -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/2876975205/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: An apt opportunity to share this wonderful passage again: Sydneyites ... send carriages behind their locomotives as tall as ordinary houses. ... It was some time before we ventured on board one of these moving buildings. ... As we went along we had splendid views into bed-rooms, bath-rooms, store-rooms, top garrets, and generally the upper quarters of the houses which lined a street. Now and then a hand would suddenly snap down a blind. - Mark Kershaw, Colonial Facts and Fictions - Humorous Sketches (London: Chatto & Windus, 1886), pp. 102-4 quoted in Louise Johnson, Gaslight Sydney (Sydney: George Allen & Unwin, 1984), p. 48.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Well you knew I'd pipe up at some point. The hotel was the Albion Hotel. The licensee: Thomas Punch :-) It can be seen better in these images from 1909 and 1934 It got fancied up and the facade redone sometime after 1934, I think in the late 30s or early 40s. I don't know a lot about this one I'm afraid ... need to do more research! There's quite a lot of images out there on picture Australia of this corner over the years.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] Great stuff. It never occurred to me that the building might still be there (minus the awning, plus extra floors) . Google Street View

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] cheers! I'm not sure how much is original. I think they completely redid the facade in the 30s and the interior has probably been completely changed I would imagine. Amazingly the building doesn't seem to be on the State Heritage Register, so without going to the City of Sydney Archives, there's not much more I can say about it!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] Thanks to you,  we know far more about this than ever!

AB

comment.author: 40765792@N00
comment._content: Isn't there some women only social club upstairs in that building?

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: On the other corner (now David Jones) from 1883 was the original Sydney Boys' High School on the ground floor and Sydney Girls' High School on the upper floor of a two storey building. Well overcrowded, the Boys' School moved to Mary Anne Street, Ultimo, into buildings adjacent to the Sydney Techincal College, before the Boys' School again moved in 1928 to Moore Park.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/63385174@N06] Thanks for adding this info.

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: Sydney Boys' High School at Ultimo...... www.powerhousemuseum.com/imageservices/index.php/2011/01/... And this.... acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/search/simpleSearch.aspx?authority=pla... It seems Ultimo comprised a co-location of the Sydney Technological Museum (nearest Harris Street), the Sydney Technical College and Sydney Boys' High School.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63385174@N06] Hi GrenadierGuardsDmr, I'd never seen that photo of the school before, thanks for sharing it. I see that the State Library of Victoria hold a copy print of the photograph, which you can zoom in on - digital.slv.vic.gov.au/view/action/nmets.do?DOCCHOICE=302... [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] Does anyone know of a photo that shows the buildings to the left of the Albion Hotel? comment._content: Found it! Newlands House, 141-143 Elizabeth Street - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=166436

comment.author: 69812947@N04
comment._content: Hi.  I am not in Sydney myself - does the Albion hotel still exist?  I am trying to track down some information on a previous publican  - William A Cahill.  Not having much luck with my searches - any suggestions?  Lucy

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Hi Lucy. The building is still there but has been completely 'remodeled' and is a retail store. Hermes I think. What sort of info do you want on the publican and when approximately did he live and hold the license? I can probably point you in a few directions if you like?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69812947@N04] Yes, Lucy, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/agrippinamaior] is the Hotel expert around here! I did a quick Trove for "William A Cahill" and found a couple or references to Licencing in 1851 (no.199) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/12926958?searchTerm=Will... and 1852 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/12934815?searchTerm=Will... And Funeral Notices in 1871 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13245837?searchTerm=Will...

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] hehe thanks! Lucy you should also look at the licensing records at State Records NSW www.records.nsw.gov.au/state-archives/guides-and-finding-... Unfortunately I didn't come up with anything in their licensee index search but it might be worth contacting them directly to see if there is any further information. You should also be able to find all the years he was licensee by looking through the Sands Directories for the years around 1851 & 1852.

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] You could say I troved for ... ! Love verbing a noun :-)
